title: 104_hr2341
content: The Act titled "FEHBP-Medical Savings Account Promotion Act of 1995" permits contributions towards medical savings accounts through the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program (FEHBP). The FEHBP-Medical Savings Account Promotion Act of 1995 allows government contributions to medical savings accounts for employees or annuitants enrolled in catastrophic plans under section 8903(5) of title 5, United States Code. The government contribution is in addition to the existing contribution and is based on the difference between the maximum allowed contribution and the actual government contribution. The FEHBP-Medical Savings Account Promotion Act of 1995 allows government contributions to medical savings accounts for individuals enrolled in catastrophic plans. The contributions are paid into a designated account specified by the individual and follow the timing of contributions under subsection (b). The term 'medical savings account' is defined as per the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The FEHBP-Medical Savings Account Promotion Act of 1995 allows government contributions to medical savings accounts for individuals enrolled in catastrophic plans, which provide benefits of specific types. Amendments are made to allow payment of the full amount of charge for catastrophic plans and to specify the types of benefits covered under these plans. The FEHBP-Medical Savings Account Promotion Act of 1995 allows government contributions to medical savings accounts for individuals enrolled in catastrophic plans. Amendments specify the types of benefits covered under these plans and the effective date of the changes. The trust governing instrument must meet specific requirements: contributions must be in cash, trustee must be a bank or insurance company, no investment in life insurance contracts, and assets cannot be commingled except in common trust or investment funds. The trust governing instrument must meet specific requirements for contributions, trustee qualifications, and asset management. The interest in an individual's account balance is nonforfeitable, and qualified medical expenses include payments for medical care and long-term care insurance for the account holder, spouse, and dependents. The term "account holder" refers to the individual for whom the medical savings account was established. Rules similar to those for deductions for rollovers apply to this section. Section 219(f)(3) determines the time contributions are considered made, while section 219(f)(5) pertains to employer payments. Section 408(h) relates to custodial accounts.
